questions.neutral: You look like you've seen some things - rough day?

hobby.message: Found any new political literature lately?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I explore the city's underground. It's a different world down there.
neutral_answer: Yeah, it's been a bit much lately.
Been poking around the tunnels again. Not many safe places aboveground now.
Stuff changed after those billboard leaks. Even my usual routes are crowded.
People everywhere, never used to see that.
Rough day? You could say that.
I unwind by roaming utility tunnels, fixing old systems, brewing a little hooch.
Used to be quiet down there before all that data hit the screens.
Now I’m dodging strangers who think the underground’s backstage.
Wasn’t always this lively.
It’s been busier than I like.
I’ve got this thing for exploring sealed tunnels and old data centers.
Usually go solo, clear my head, trade stories with machines.
After the info dump, everyone's scurrying down there—activists, lost souls, taggers.
Makes it harder to find a quiet spot to think.
Still, the city’s heartbeat is clearest underground.
You know, crawling around locked tunnels is my real pastime.
I keep old city systems breathing, patch leaks, sometimes just drink homebrew and listen to pipes.
Lately, since all those BCI secrets lit the city up, my solo haunts are getting crowded.
Underground’s now full of folk trading stories and passwords, not just rats and cables.
I kind of miss the quiet, but there’s something growing down there.
Feels like Stenograd’s real network isn’t digital, it’s the people talking in the dark.
Funny how trouble brings company, even where you’d least expect it.
You ever wander tunnels under a city? That’s my hobby—call it urban spelunking.
Started as a work thing, fixing forgotten switches, keeping old flows stable.
Turned into homebrew sessions under pipes and swapping ghost stories with myself.
Since I leaked those Council files, it’s a whole migration down there.
Now, everyone’s listening for forbidden chatter, passing notes, sharing maps.
I help folks rig analog radios—nothing digital lasts long these days.
Sometimes they even thank me for the leaks, face-to-face.
Feels like I built the only place left where the city can speak freely.
hobby_answer: No, doesn't get boring. Plenty left to see underground.
Especially with all these crowds spilling into the tunnels now.
Used to be just pipes and echoes. Different lately.
Everyone's hiding or sneaking, thanks to the blackout.
Easy to get in trouble down there now.
Still exploring, never got tired of old infrastructure.
Lately, it's busy—people camping, leaving signs under the city.
System failures made the tunnels more popular than I’d like.
Saw fresh tags everywhere after the last protest blackout.
Hobby's gotten crowded, riskier lately.
Privacy’s thinner than it used to be.
Nope, never boring—always a new jammed hatch or faulty relay.
Used to be quiet down there. Not anymore, everyone’s hiding or signaling.
Since they cut comms, analog radios echo louder than my footsteps.
I dodged more people in one tunnel walk than I used to in a month.
Found some old council tags repurposed as meet-up codes last week.
Kind of funny, seeing the system’s ghosts underground now.
Keeps me sharp, at least.
Never boring—the tunnels are a map of new lives lately.
People use old service ducts as message boards now.
Heard council scripts traded for bread and passwords in a relay vault.
The protest blackout pushed everyone my way. Some work together, some hide.
I used to wander solo. Nowadays, you trip over three mutual aid crews every tunnel.
Pulled two strangers out of a jammed hatch after a teach-in.
Whole city’s on the move below the grid.
Feels like history’s writing itself under our boots.
Boring? Never. These tunnels kept me sane when the city tried to erase me.
Every leak or short circuit’s a story. I remember when I learned to reroute city power drunk in sector five.
Now survivalists and teachers set up barter posts where inspectors used to drink.
Met someone last week using my own leak as a meeting code—messy, but proud, really.
After the billboard hack, everyone’s got questions in the dark.
It’s strange guiding a crowd through tunnels that were secret for years.
Sometimes I miss the silence, but watching neighborhoods build networks from scrap—it’s worth the chaos.
Funny—my hobby trained me for all this rebellion.
Guess the city finally caught up to the old rats.
